abstract.text: Creates one set of matching criteria for HID devices.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A catch-all for uncommon or device specific criteria not listed above. This parameter is typically only for advanced users that need additional control over the matching process.
method is the only way to create matching criteria for discovering HID devices connected to the system. All parameters are optional; if none are specified, every discoverable device is matched.
are used by being passed to

communicating-with-human-interface-devic.alt: An image showing the Swift logo on the left. Three arrows emerge from it and point to the right. The first arrow points to a game controller. The second arrow points to a mouse. The third arrow points to a keyboard.

abstract.text: Interact with keyboards, mice, and other human interface devices.
Interact with and obtain data from devices such as keyboards and mice.
The localization codes that some HID devices declare to specify conformance to a certain format or language.
A helper for discovering human interface devices (HID) connected to the system.
Matching criteria used to filter HID devices.
A list of usages supported by the device.
Creates one set of matching criteria for HID devices.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the device is built-in to the system or external.
A localization code that specifies the HID compliant localization code.
The location ID for the device.
The manufacturer of the device.
The model number for the device.
The HID specification compliant usage for the device.
The product name for the device.
The product ID for the device.
The serial number of the device.
The data transport for the device.
A unique ID for the device.
The vendor ID for the device.
The version of the device.
Creates an asynchronous stream that receives notifications for devices of interest.
Common transport types that transmit data to or from a HID device.
A type to represent HID usage pages.
A collection whose elements are key-value pairs.
A Unicode string value that is a collection of characters.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A 32-bit unsigned integer value type.
A 64-bit unsigned integer value type.
The protocol to which all classes implicitly conform.
